docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of cities across China are turning to deep-pocketed private investors to help foot the bill for public infrastructure and services.

headline.main: As China Reduces Local Spending, Cities Woo Private Investors

docs.abstract: Hundreds of deeply-indebted Chinese municipalities are trying to attract local and foreign investors to help pay for infrastructure and services; low-cost government loans from Beijing are drying up as officials fret over rising debt; trend is exemplified by city of Weifang in eastern China, which has had early success in attracting private capital.
docs.snippet: Hundreds of cities across China are turning to deep-pocketed private investors to help foot the bill for public infrastructure and services.

byline.contributor: Neil Gough reported from Hong Kong, and Cao Li contributed research from Weifang, China.
byline.original: By NEIL GOUGH and CAO LI

docs.lead_paragraph: The argument for the cost savings from universal health coverage makes some intuitive sense, but it’s not backed up by research.

headline.main: No, Giving More People Health Insurance Doesn’t Save Money
headline.print_headline: Conventional Wisdom Clashes With Data on Health Care Savings

docs.abstract: The Upshot; government actuaries at Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services estimate that health spending jumped by 5.5 percent in 2014, when millions of people first obtained insurance under Affordable Care Act; rise would be biggest country has experienced in five years, contradicting idea that expanded coverage will save system money.
docs.snippet: The argument for the cost savings from universal health coverage makes some intuitive sense, but it’s not backed up by research.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans seeking their party's 2016 presidential nomination have the challenging task of trying to stand out among the 17 candidates in the race, and Thursday's televised debate was the first opportunity for the party to start whittling down its choices. So it's no surprise that the candidates had a vested interest in puffing up their own records as governors, senators and public figures. And some of them just got the facts wrong.

headline.main: FACT CHECK: GOP Candidates Veer From the Truth in 1st Debate
headline.print_headline: FACT CHECK: GOP Candidates Veer From the Truth in 1st Debate

docs.snippet: Republicans seeking their party's 2016 presidential nomination have the challenging task of trying to stand out among the 17 candidates in the race, and Thursday's televised debate was the first opportunity for the party to start whittling down its...

headline.main: Living With Cancer: Alone and Ghosted

docs.abstract: When cancer patients need help, they are often surprised to find that long-trusted friends have disappeared.
docs.snippet: When cancer patients need help, they are often surprised to find that long-trusted friends have disappeared.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Federal Reserve puzzles over what is holding back U.S. wages and productivity six years into the economic recovery, a pasta sauce company in New Jersey may offer some answers.

docs.lead_paragraph: North Carolina's largest health insurer says higher-than-anticipated costs after two years of selling federally subsidized coverage has forced it to seek premium increases even greater than it thought would be necessary two months ago.

headline.main: Blue Cross Raises Rate Hike Sought on Affordable Care Plans
headline.print_headline: Blue Cross Raises Rate Hike Sought on Affordable Care Plans

docs.lead_paragraph: Slightly more Americans filed for unemployment benefits last week, but their numbers remain near historic lows in a sign that the job market is healthy.

docs.lead_paragraph: British private healthcare group Bupa [BUPAI.UL] has extended an 800 million pound syndicated credit facility by three years to 2020 at least to strengthen its capital buffers, its chief executive said.

headline.print_headline: British Healthcare Firm Bupa Extends 800 Mllion Pound Credit Line
